title: Google Search Engine Optimization (SEO) Setup Guide
text:
Your Quarto website is now configured for better search engine indexing:



Quarto automatically generates sitemap.xml at https://mcnakhaee.com/sitemap.xml
This helps Google discover all your pages





Created robots.txt file that tells search engines they can crawl your site
Points to your sitemap





Added description, keywords, and Open Graph tags
Enabled Twitter Card support
Added structured metadata to homepage





Blog RSS feed available at https://mcnakhaee.com/blog/index.xml








Go to Google Search Console
Click “Start Now” and sign in with your Google account
Click “Add Property”
Enter your domain: mcnakhaee.com




Choose one of these verification methods:



Google will give you an HTML file to download (e.g., google1234567890abcdef.html)
Place this file in the root of your website directory
Render your site: quarto render
Commit and push to GitHub
Wait for Netlify to deploy
Click “Verify” in Google Search Console





Google will give you a meta tag like: <meta name="google-site-verification" content="abc123..." />
Add this to your index.qmd frontmatter:
---
title: "Muhammad Nakhaee"
google-site-verification: "abc123..."
---
Render, commit, push, and verify






Once verified, in Google Search Console, go to “Sitemaps”
Enter: sitemap.xml
Click “Submit”





Go to Google Analytics
Create a new property for your website
Get your Measurement ID (format: G-XXXXXXXXXX)
Update _quarto.yml with your real ID:
google-analytics: "G-YOUR-ACTUAL-ID"
Render, commit, and push








Descriptive page titles
Meta descriptions
Semantic HTML structure
Mobile-responsive design
Fast loading (static site)
HTTPS (via Netlify)
Social media meta tags





Add alt text to all images - Helps with accessibility and SEO
Internal linking - Link between related posts and pages
Regular content updates - Post consistently to your blog
Quality content - Focus on valuable, original content
Share on social media - Increases visibility and backlinks





After submitting to Google Search Console: - Wait 24-48 hours for Google to crawl your site - Check coverage report in Search Console - Use site search: site:mcnakhaee.com in Google to see indexed pages



Google Search Console provides: - Number of indexed pages - Search queries bringing traffic - Click-through rates - Mobile usability issues - Security problems



# Render your site locally
quarto render

# Add files and commit
git add .
git commit -m "Update SEO configuration"

# Push to deploy
git push origin quarto




Google Search Console Help
Quarto SEO Documentation
Netlify SEO Guide


Note: Google indexing can take several days to weeks. Be patient and keep creating quality content!

title: Deployment Guide for Netlify
text:
Backup your old distill blog (optional but recommended):
git checkout -b backup-distill
git push origin backup-distill
Switch to main branch and update:
git checkout main
Add your new Quarto website files:
git add .
git commit -m "Migrate from distill to Quarto"
git push origin main




Go to your Netlify site dashboard:

Site settings → Build & deploy → Build settings
Update the settings:

Build command: quarto render
Publish directory: _site

Environment variables → Add:

Key: QUARTO_VERSION
Value: 1.4.0 (or latest version)






Click Deploys → Trigger deploy → Deploy site
Your new Quarto site will build and deploy!






If you prefer to deploy manually without CI/CD:

Build your site locally:
quarto render
Deploy the _site folder:

Drag and drop the _site folder to Netlify’s deploy page
Or use Netlify CLI:
npm install -g netlify-cli
netlify deploy --prod --dir=_site







netlify.toml - Netlify configuration file
.gitignore - Already excludes _site folder






Remove old distill files: Delete these if they exist:

_site.yml (replaced by _quarto.yml)
Old R Markdown files (.Rmd)
distill-specific configuration

Custom domain: If you have a custom domain, keep your DNS settings in Netlify
Redirects: The netlify.toml includes a catch-all redirect for client-side routing
Build time: First build may take 2-3 minutes







Make sure QUARTO_VERSION environment variable is set in Netlify.



Clear your browser cache or do a hard refresh (Ctrl+Shift+R).



Check that publish directory is set to _site (not _site/ or docs).






Quarto Publishing Guide
Netlify Documentation

title: Talks & Presentations
text:
I enjoy sharing knowledge and insights with the community through talks, workshops, and presentations. Here’s a collection of my speaking engagements.





Conference: Tech Summit 2025
Date: October 15, 2025
Location: Virtual
An overview of modern web development practices, including React, TypeScript, and best practices for building scalable applications.






NoteResources




Slides (PDF)
Video Recording
Code Examples







Event: Data Science Meetup
Date: August 22, 2025
Location: San Francisco, CA
Exploring techniques for creating effective data visualizations that tell compelling stories and drive insights.
Key Topics: - Choosing the right chart type - Color theory for data viz - Interactive vs. static visualizations - Tools and libraries overview






NoteResources




Slides (PDF)
Demo Code







Event: Developer Bootcamp
Date: June 10, 2025
Location: Virtual
A hands-on workshop covering RESTful API development, authentication, and deployment best practices.
What Attendees Learned: - REST API fundamentals - Express.js framework - Database integration - Security best practices - Testing and deployment






NoteResources




Workshop Materials
GitHub Repository










Conference: WebDev Conference 2024
Date: November 5, 2024
Location: New York, NY
Participated in a panel discussion about emerging trends and the future direction of web development technologies.




Event: Local Tech Meetup
Date: September 18, 2024
Location: Seattle, WA
A 15-minute lightning talk sharing practical tips for maintaining high code quality in fast-paced development environments.





I’m available to speak on the following topics:


Web Development - Modern JavaScript/TypeScript - React and frontend frameworks - Performance optimization - Responsive design


Data Science - Data visualization - Python for data analysis - Machine learning basics - Statistical analysis


Best Practices - Code quality and testing - CI/CD pipelines - Developer productivity - Technical documentation






I’m always interested in speaking opportunities! If you’d like me to speak at your event, please reach out.






TipContact




Email: speaking@example.com
Topics: See above or suggest your own
Format: Talks, workshops, panels, or podcasts

Note: Replace with your actual contact information.






Looking for older presentations? Check out my GitHub repository where I archive all presentation materials, slides, and code examples.

title: Modern Web Application
text: This project is a modern web application that demonstrates best practices in full-stack development. It features a responsive design, user authentication, and real-time data updates.

title: Modern Web Application
text: This project is a modern web application that demonstrates best practices in full-stack development. It features a responsive design, user authentication, and real-time data updates.

title: Modern Web Application
text:
Key Features

Responsive Design: Works seamlessly across all devices
User Authentication: Secure login and registration system
Real-time Updates: Live data synchronization using WebSockets
Modern Stack: Built with React, Node.js, Express, and MongoDB

title: Modern Web Application
text:
Technologies Used


Frontend - React - TypeScript - Tailwind CSS


Backend - Node.js - Express - MongoDB


Tools - Git - Docker - Jest


Deployment - Vercel - MongoDB Atlas - GitHub Actions

title: Modern Web Application
text:
Challenges & Solutions
One of the main challenges was implementing real-time updates efficiently. We solved this by using WebSockets for live data synchronization, which significantly improved the user experience.

title: {palmerpenguins}
text: {palmerpenguins} is a Python package that provides easy access to the Palmer Penguins dataset, making it simple to load this popular dataset for data science education, exploration, and visualization in Python. This is the Python equivalent of the popular R package of the same name.

title: {palmerpenguins}
text: {palmerpenguins} is a Python package that provides easy access to the Palmer Penguins dataset, making it simple to load this popular dataset for data science education, exploration, and visualization in Python. This is the Python equivalent of the popular R package of the same name.

title: {palmerpenguins}
text:
About Palmer Penguins
The Palmer Penguins dataset is a modern alternative to the classic Iris dataset. It contains size measurements for three penguin species observed on three islands in the Palmer Archipelago, Antarctica.
The dataset includes: - 344 penguins across 3 species - 7 variables including species, island, bill dimensions, flipper length, body mass, and sex - Real data collected by Dr. Kristen Gorman at Palmer Station, Antarctica

title: {palmerpenguins}
text:
Why This Package?
While the Palmer Penguins dataset is available in R, Python users needed an easy way to access it. This package:

Simplifies Data Loading: One-line import of the dataset
Multiple Formats: Returns pandas DataFrames or raw data
Consistent API: Follows Python conventions and best practices
Well-Documented: Clear examples and use cases
Lightweight: Minimal dependencies

title: {palmerpenguins}
text:
Key Features


For Data Scientists - Quick dataset access - Pandas integration - Perfect for teaching - Ideal for testing code


Package Features - Simple API - Type hints - Comprehensive tests - PyPI distribution

title: {palmerpenguins}
text:
Technologies Used

Python: Core language
pandas: Data manipulation
pytest: Testing framework
setuptools: Package distribution
GitHub Actions: CI/CD

title: {palmerpenguins}
text:
Installation
pip install palmerpenguins

title: {palmerpenguins}
text:
Basic Usage
from palmerpenguins import load_penguins

# Load the penguins dataset
penguins = load_penguins()

# Start exploring
print(penguins.head())
print(penguins.describe())

title: {palmerpenguins}
text:
Use Cases
Perfect for: - Teaching: Introduce data science concepts with real data - Learning: Practice visualization and analysis techniques - Testing: Quick dataset for prototyping code - Examples: Demonstrate statistical methods and visualizations

title: {palmerpenguins}
text:
Example Analysis
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns
from palmerpenguins import load_penguins

# Load data
penguins = load_penguins()

# Create visualization
sns.scatterplot(
    data=penguins,
    x="bill_length_mm",
    y="bill_depth_mm",
    hue="species"
)
plt.title("Palmer Penguins: Bill Dimensions")
plt.show()

title: {palmerpenguins}
text:
Project Links






TipAccess the Package




GitHub Repository: github.com/mcnakhaee/palmerpenguin
PyPI: Install via pip install palmerpenguins

title: {palmerpenguins}
text:
Impact
This package: - Makes quality educational datasets more accessible to Python users - Supports the data science teaching community - Promotes the use of modern, ethically-sourced datasets - Contributes to the Python data science ecosystem

title: {palmerpenguins}
text:
What I Learned
Developing this package taught me: - Python package development and distribution - Working with PyPI and package management - Writing effective documentation - The importance of good educational resources - How to contribute to the open-source data science community - Testing and continuous integration best practices

title: {palmerpenguins}
text:
Credits
Dataset originally published by: - Dr. Kristen Gorman: Palmer Station, Antarctica LTER - Dr. Allison Horst: Artwork and R package

Open source project available on GitHub and PyPI

title: Data Analysis Dashboard
text: This data analysis dashboard provides interactive visualizations and insights from complex datasets. It’s designed to make data exploration intuitive and accessible.

title: Data Analysis Dashboard
text: This data analysis dashboard provides interactive visualizations and insights from complex datasets. It’s designed to make data exploration intuitive and accessible.

title: Data Analysis Dashboard
text:
Key Features

Interactive Visualizations: Dynamic charts and graphs using Plotly
Data Processing: Efficient data handling with Pandas
Real-time Filtering: Interactive filters for data exploration
Export Options: Export reports in multiple formats

title: Data Analysis Dashboard
text:
Technologies Used
# Core libraries used in this project
import pandas as pd
import plotly.express as px
import dash
from dash import dcc, html
Tech Stack: - Python 3.11 - Pandas for data manipulation - Plotly & Dash for visualizations - NumPy for numerical computations

title: Data Analysis Dashboard
text:
Project Highlights

Data Processing Pipeline
The dashboard processes large datasets efficiently using:

Data Cleaning: Automated preprocessing and validation
Transformation: Feature engineering and aggregation
Visualization: Multiple chart types and interactive elements



Performance Optimization

Implemented caching for faster load times
Optimized queries for large datasets
Used lazy loading for better UX

title: Data Analysis Dashboard
text:
Use Cases
This dashboard has been used for: - Business intelligence reporting - Sales data analysis - Customer behavior tracking - Performance metrics monitoring






TipTry It Out



The dashboard is designed to work with various data sources. You can connect your own CSV files or databases to visualize your data.

title: Data Analysis Dashboard
text:
Code Sample
Here’s an example of creating an interactive visualization:
def create_chart(df, x_col, y_col):
    fig = px.scatter(df, x=x_col, y=y_col, 
                     title=f'{y_col} vs {x_col}',
                     hover_data=df.columns)
    return fig

title: Data Analysis Dashboard
text:
Links

GitHub: View Source Code
Documentation: Read More


Project completed: September 2025

title: Package Requirements for Migrated Blog Posts
text:
This document lists the R and Python packages referenced in the migrated blog posts.


Location: blog/posts/trump-speech-readability/index.qmd



tidyverse - Data manipulation and visualization
reticulate - R interface to Python
ggthemes - Additional themes for ggplot2
us2020election - Custom package with US election speeches data (https://github.com/mcnakhaee/us2020election)
ggridges - Ridge plots for visualizations
showtext (optional) - Font management
knitr - R Markdown support





numpy - Numerical computing
pandas - Data manipulation
textstat - Text readability metrics (https://github.com/shivam5992/textstat)






install.packages(c("tidyverse", "reticulate", "ggthemes", "ggridges", "showtext", "knitr"))

# Install us2020election from GitHub
# install.packages("devtools")
# devtools::install_github("mcnakhaee/us2020election")



pip install numpy pandas textstat






Location: blog/posts/covid-19-netherlands/index.qmd



tidyverse - Data manipulation and visualization
CoronaWatchNL - Custom package for Netherlands COVID-19 data (https://github.com/mcnakhaee/CoronaWatchNL)
sf - Spatial data handling
gganimate - Animated visualizations
santoku - Data binning/chopping
lubridate - Date/time handling (part of tidyverse)
foreign - Reading foreign data formats
knitr - R Markdown support






install.packages(c("tidyverse", "sf", "gganimate", "santoku", "lubridate", "foreign", "knitr"))

# Install CoronaWatchNL from GitHub
# install.packages("devtools")
# devtools::install_github("mcnakhaee/CoronaWatchNL")






Both posts are currently configured with eval=FALSE for all code chunks. This means: - ✅ The code is displayed for educational purposes - ✅ The site renders without requiring all packages to be installed - ✅ No Python environment configuration is needed - ✅ Images and GIFs (if present in post directories) will still display



If you want to execute the code:

Install all required packages (see above)
For the Trump speech post, configure Python environment:

Uncomment the reticulate configuration in the setup chunk
Ensure you have a conda environment or use reticulate::use_python()

Change eval=FALSE to eval=TRUE in the chunks you want to run
Ensure data files and dependencies are available





The us2020election and CoronaWatchNL packages are custom packages that need to be installed from GitHub
Font configuration (Lobster, Poppins Light) may require system fonts to be installed
Animation GIFs should be placed in the respective post directories if you want them to display
The posts are currently optimized for display without execution, perfect for portfolio/documentation purposes

title: Package Requirements for Migrated Blog Posts
text:
Location: blog/posts/trump-speech-readability/index.qmd



tidyverse - Data manipulation and visualization
reticulate - R interface to Python
ggthemes - Additional themes for ggplot2
us2020election - Custom package with US election speeches data (https://github.com/mcnakhaee/us2020election)
ggridges - Ridge plots for visualizations
showtext (optional) - Font management
knitr - R Markdown support





numpy - Numerical computing
pandas - Data manipulation
textstat - Text readability metrics (https://github.com/shivam5992/textstat)






install.packages(c("tidyverse", "reticulate", "ggthemes", "ggridges", "showtext", "knitr"))

# Install us2020election from GitHub
# install.packages("devtools")
# devtools::install_github("mcnakhaee/us2020election")



pip install numpy pandas textstat

title: Package Requirements for Migrated Blog Posts
text:
Location: blog/posts/covid-19-netherlands/index.qmd



tidyverse - Data manipulation and visualization
CoronaWatchNL - Custom package for Netherlands COVID-19 data (https://github.com/mcnakhaee/CoronaWatchNL)
sf - Spatial data handling
gganimate - Animated visualizations
santoku - Data binning/chopping
lubridate - Date/time handling (part of tidyverse)
foreign - Reading foreign data formats
knitr - R Markdown support






install.packages(c("tidyverse", "sf", "gganimate", "santoku", "lubridate", "foreign", "knitr"))

# Install CoronaWatchNL from GitHub
# install.packages("devtools")
# devtools::install_github("mcnakhaee/CoronaWatchNL")

title: Package Requirements for Migrated Blog Posts
text: Both posts are currently configured with eval=FALSE for all code chunks. This means: - ✅ The code is displayed for educational purposes - ✅ The site renders without requiring all packages to be installed - ✅ No Python environment configuration is needed - ✅ Images and GIFs (if present in post directories) will still display

title: Package Requirements for Migrated Blog Posts
text:
If you want to execute the code:

Install all required packages (see above)
For the Trump speech post, configure Python environment:

Uncomment the reticulate configuration in the setup chunk
Ensure you have a conda environment or use reticulate::use_python()

Change eval=FALSE to eval=TRUE in the chunks you want to run
Ensure data files and dependencies are available

title: Package Requirements for Migrated Blog Posts
text:
The us2020election and CoronaWatchNL packages are custom packages that need to be installed from GitHub
Font configuration (Lobster, Poppins Light) may require system fonts to be installed
Animation GIFs should be placed in the respective post directories if you want them to display
The posts are currently optimized for display without execution, perfect for portfolio/documentation purposes

title: Covid-19 Trends in the Netherlands
text:
Two weeks ago, I made a visualization that shows how Covid-19 cases spread in the Netherlands from the beginning of March and how grim the situation looked. However, someone pointed out the fact that the number of tests has increased significantly. It means that my plot may exaggerate the Covid-19 situation in the Netherlands. Unfortunately, I could not find testing data for each Dutch municipality. Instead, I decided to use hospitalization admissions and deceased cases to see if we can indeed see a massive spread in the second wave of Covid-19 cases in the Netherlands.
Code
library(tidyverse)
library(CoronaWatchNL)
library(sf)
library(gganimate)
library(santoku)
library(lubridate)
library(foreign)
theme_set(theme_void())
theme_update(
  #plot.background = element_rect(fill = '#FDF6E3',color = '#FDF6E3'),
  text = element_text(family = 'Poppins Light'),
  plot.subtitle = element_text(
    family = 'Poppins Light',
    size = 10,
    margin = margin(b = 10)
  ),
  plot.title = element_text(
    family = 'Poppins Light',
    size = 12,
    margin = margin(t = 10, b = 10)
  )
)
I created an R package called CoronaWatchNL that allows you to access a wide range of Covid-19 datasets. I’ll use this package in this post to get Covid-19 cases, hospital admissions, and deaths for Dutch municipalities.
Code
municipalBoundaries <- st_read(
    "https://geodata.nationaalgeoregister.nl/cbsgebiedsindelingen/wfs?request=GetFeature&service=WFS&version=2.0.0&typeName=cbs_gemeente_2020_gegeneraliseerd&outputFormat=json"
  )

daily_cases_per_municpality <- get_daily_cases_per_municipality()
populatuon_per_region <- get_population_per_region()

daily_cases_per_municpality <- daily_cases_per_municpality %>%
  inner_join(populatuon_per_region, by = c('Municipality_name' = 'Regions')) %>%
  mutate(
    Date_of_publication = as_date(Date_of_publication),
    avg_daily_total_cases = 100000 * as.numeric(Total_reported) / as.numeric(`Bevolking op 1 januari (aantal)`),
    avg_daily_hospital_admissions = 100000 * as.numeric(Hospital_admission) / as.numeric(`Bevolking op 1 januari (aantal)`),
    avg_daily_deceased = 100000 * as.numeric(Deceased) / as.numeric(`Bevolking op 1 januari (aantal)`)
  )
I compute the weekly average number of Covid-19 cases, hospitalizations, and deaths per 100,000 inhabitants in each municipality in the Netherlands. The following piece of code shows how I did this using R.
Code
weekly_cases <- daily_cases_per_municpality %>%
  mutate(week = round_date(Date_of_publication , unit = 'week'))

weekly_cases_per_municpality <- weekly_cases %>%
  group_by(Municipality_name, week) %>%
  summarise(
    avg_weekly_total_cases = mean(avg_daily_total_cases),
    avg_weekly_hospital_admissions = mean(avg_daily_hospital_admissions),
    avg_weekly_deceased = mean(avg_daily_deceased)) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  mutate(
    d_avg_weekly_total_cases = chop(avg_weekly_total_cases, c(0, 0, 0.5, 1, 5, 12, 20, 35, 55, 80, 100)),
    d_avg_hospital_admissions = chop(
      avg_weekly_hospital_admissions,
      c(0, 0, 0.5, 1, 2, 3, 5, 7, 9, 10, 15)),
    d_avg_weekly_deceased = chop(avg_weekly_deceased, c(0, 0, 0.1, 0.5, 1, 1.5, 2, 2.5, 3, 5)))

data_weekly <- municipalBoundaries %>%
  right_join(weekly_cases_per_municpality,
             by = c(statnaam = "Municipality_name"))
I will create an animation that shows how Covid-19 cases spread in the Netherlands and which municipalities were and are hit hardest by the pandemic.
Code
make_animation <- function(data, var_name, pal, title) {
  var_name <- rlang::enquo(var_name)
  data %>%
    #filter(week > '2020-10-01') %>%
    ggplot() +
    geom_sf(aes(fill = !!var_name), color = 'gray95') +
    scale_fill_manual(values  = pal) +
    coord_sf(datum = NA) +
    labs(
      title = title,
      subtitle = 'Date: {current_frame}',
      fill = 'Counts per 100,000',
      caption = 'Source: RIVM'
    ) +
    transition_manual(week, cumulative = T) +
    ease_aes("sine") +
    enter_fade(alpha = 0.5) +
    exit_fade(alpha = 0.5)
}

title: Covid-19 Trends in the Netherlands
text:
Covid-19 Cases
The first animation shows the number of infections in each municipality, from the start of the pandemic in February until recently. As you can see, the second wave, which began in late September, looks really terrifying. Note that there are some municipalities for which no data is available.


Code
pal_cases <- c(
      'gray95',
      '#fee440',
      '#FFBA08',
      '#FAA307',
      '#F48C06',
      '#E85D04',
      '#DC2F02',
      '#D00000',
      '#9D0208',
      '#6A040F',
      '#370617',
      '#03071e'
    )
make_animation(data_weekly,d_avg_weekly_total_cases,pal_cases,'The Average Weekly Number of Covid-19 Cases\nper 100,000 Inhabitants in the Netherlands')

title: Covid-19 Trends in the Netherlands
text:
Hospital Admissions
If we look at the number of hospital admissions, we see a different story. It seems that the number of hospitalizations was higher during the first wave of Covid-19 compared to the second wave, and mostly the southern parts of the Netherlands were hit harder than the rest of the Netherlands.


Code
pal_patients <- c(
      'gray95',
      '#caf0f8',
      '#ade8f4',
      '#90e0ef',
      '#48cae4',
      '#00b4d8',
      '#0096c7',
      '#0077b6',
      '#023e8a',
      '#03045e',
      '#03071e'
)
make_animation(data_weekly,d_avg_hospital_admissions,pal_patients,'The Average Weekly Number of Hospital Admissions\nper 100,000 Inhabitants in the Netherlands')

title: Covid-19 Trends in the Netherlands
text:
Deaths
The trend for deceased patients looks similar to that of hospital admissions. The average number of deaths during the first wave of coronavirus was higher than the average number of deaths during the second wave.


Code
pal_deceased <- c(
      'gray95',
      '#fdc5f5',
     '#e0aaff',
      '#c77dff',
      '#9d4edd',
      '#7b2cbf',
      '#5a189a',
      '#3c096c',
      '#240046',
      '#10002b'
)
make_animation(data_weekly,d_avg_weekly_deceased,pal_deceased,'The Average Weekly Number of Deceased Patients\nper 100,000 Inhabitants in the Netherlands')

title: Covid-19 Trends in the Netherlands
text:
Conclusion
These different animations show us two distinct trends. On the one hand, we can see the number of confirmed cases rose rapidly during the second wave to affect almost all regions. On the other hand, the number of hospitalizations and deaths during the second wave slightly decreased. This might suggest that the rise in the number of cases is mainly driven by an increase in the number of tests. Alternatively, the virus might have become less deadly and severe.

title: How Easy Is It to Understand What Donald Trump Says?
text:
Aside from their political differences, Donald Trump and Barack Obama have very contrasting personalities, traits, and characters. Obama is known to be a great communicator and an articulate speaker whose speeches are used in English classes to show how one should speak proper English. On the other hand, Trump is not the most eloquent English speaker or US president in history. Every now and then, you can find a clip on the web where Donald Trump is being mocked for the way he speaks or mispronounces words. This is so obvious that even non-native English speakers can notice how Trump’s speeches are very simple and inarticulate. Of course, this was not a bad thing for Trump at all. Actually, almost every political analyst that you see on the news talks about the fact that a vast majority of Trump’s fervent supporters are not college-educated Americans. We can attribute this to the fact that he knows how to speak to his audience and his base supporters using their language (although it is more likely that he cannot speak English better than this level).
This post will investigate how difficult it is to understand what each US politician talked about in the 2020 US Election cycle. I will use several readability metrics that can help us compute text comprehensibility. A wide range of these measures are implemented in the {textstat} Python package, and it is super easy to calculate them using this package.
I compiled a list of US Election-related speeches from rev.com and turned them into an R package called {us2020election}. I use this package as my data source for my analysis. Like some of my other posts, I use Python to perform the analysis and R to visualize my results. Now let’s get started by importing the necessary packages.
Code
library(tidyverse)
library(reticulate)
library(ggthemes)
library(us2020election)
library(ggridges)
theme_set(theme_tufte())
theme_update(legend.position = 'none',
          text = element_text(family = 'Lobster'),
          plot.title = element_text(margin = margin(t= 10,b= 5),family = 'Lobster'),
          plot.subtitle = element_text(margin = margin(b= 10),family = 'Lobster'),
          panel.background = element_rect(fill = '#FDF6E3'),
          plot.background = element_rect(fill = '#FDF6E3'))
Code
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd 
import textstat
There are several readability measures for English text included in {textstat}. Calculating these measures is very straightforward and easy. I will explain what each metric represents in more detail.
Code
us_election_speeches = r.us_election_speeches
us_election_speeches['Flesch_Reading_Ease_formula'] = us_election_speeches['text'].apply(lambda x: textstat.flesch_reading_ease(x))
us_election_speeches['gunning_fog'] = us_election_speeches['text'].apply(lambda x: textstat.gunning_fog(x))
us_election_speeches['smog_index'] = us_election_speeches['text'].apply(lambda x: textstat.smog_index(x))
us_election_speeches['automated_readability_index'] = us_election_speeches['text'].apply(lambda x: textstat.automated_readability_index(x))
us_election_speeches['coleman_liau_index'] = us_election_speeches['text'].apply(lambda x: textstat.coleman_liau_index(x))
us_election_speeches['linsear_write_formula'] = us_election_speeches['text'].apply(lambda x: textstat.linsear_write_formula(x))
us_election_speeches['dale_chall_readability_score'] = us_election_speeches['text'].apply(lambda x: textstat.dale_chall_readability_score(x))
us_election_speeches['text_standard'] = us_election_speeches['text'].apply(lambda x: textstat.text_standard(x))
us_election_speeches['text_standard_float'] = us_election_speeches['text'].apply(lambda x: textstat.text_standard(x,float_output  = True))
Let’s look at the resulting dataframe.
Code
us_election_speeches <- py$us_election_speeches 
us_election_speeches %>% 
glimpse()
Now I am going to visualize the changes in the distribution of speech complexity for each politician. To make things easier, I will select a list of politicians that I’d like to analyze in this post.
Code
speakers <- c('Barack Obama','Pete Buttigieg','Mike Pence','Elizabeth Warren','Bernie Sanders','Donald Trump','Kamala Harris','Joe Biden','Mike Bloomberg')
custom_palette <-c(
    'Mike Bloomberg' = '#4E79A7',
    'Amy Klobuchar' = '#4E79A7',
    'Joe Biden' = '#4E79A7',
    'Pete Buttigieg' = '#4E79A7',
    'Elizabeth Warren' =  '#4E79A7',
    'Barack Obama'  = '#4E79A7',
    'Bernie Sanders' = '#4E79A7',
    'Kamala Harris' = '#4E79A7',
    'Donald Trump'  = '#E15759' ,
     'Mike Pence' = '#E15759' 
  )
Also, I created a function to make ridge plots for each metric easier.
Code
create_plot <- function(metric = Flesch_Reading_Ease_formula,subtitle = subtitle) {
  metrics <- rlang::enquo(metric)
  us_election_speeches %>%
    separate_rows(speaker, sep = ',') %>%
    filter(speaker %in% speakers, type != 'Debate') %>%
    add_count(speaker) %>%
    ggplot() +
    geom_density_ridges(aes(
      x = !!metrics ,
      y = speaker,
      fill = speaker
    )) +
    labs(x = '', y = '',title = "How Easy Is It to Comprehend Different US Politicians?",subtitle = str_wrap(subtitle,width = 100)) +
    scale_fill_manual(values = custom_palette) 
}
Now, let’s look at several readability measures in more depth.

title: How Easy Is It to Understand What Donald Trump Says?
text:
Flesch Reading Ease Scores
The first readability score that I will look at is based on the Flesch Reading Ease formula. It computes the number of syllables to determine how easy a piece of text is. The maximum value of Flesch Reading Ease is 122, and there is no minimum value for it. Higher Flesch Reading Ease scores indicate that the text (speech) is easier to understand by the audience. In our case, it would show how sophisticated each politician is in terms of language use. You can find more about this metric on Wikipedia!


Code
create_plot(Flesch_Reading_Ease_formula ,
            subtitle = 'The Flesch Reading Ease scores measure the complexity of a text document. Higher scores indicate a text is easier to comprehend.')


We can interpret the scores using the following table:








Score
School level
Notes




100.00–90.00
5th grade
Very easy to read. Easily understood by an average 11-year-old student.


90.0–80.0
6th grade
Easy to read. Conversational English for consumers.


80.0–70.0
7th grade
Fairly easy to read.


70.0–60.0
8th & 9th grade
Plain English. Easily understood by 13- to 15-year-old students.


60.0–50.0
10th to 12th grade
Fairly difficult to read.


50.0–30.0
College
Difficult to read.


30.0–10.0
College graduate
Very difficult to read. Best understood by university graduates.


10.0–0.0
Professional
Extremely difficult to read. Best understood by university graduates.

title: How Easy Is It to Understand What Donald Trump Says?
text:
Gunning Fog Index
The Gunning fog index is another metric to measure the complexity of a text document. It shows how many years of education one might need to understand a piece of text. Larger values of the Gunning fog index correspond to more difficult writings.


Code
create_plot(gunning_fog,subtitle = 'The Gunning fog index measures the complexity of a text document. Larger values of the Gunning fog index correspond to more difficult writings.' )

title: How Easy Is It to Understand What Donald Trump Says?
text:
The SMOG Index
The SMOG index computes the ratio of polysyllables (words with three or more syllables) in sentences to determine text complexity.


Code
create_plot(smog_index,subtitle = 'The SMOG index measures the complexity of a text document. Larger values of the SMOG index indicate more difficult writings.' )

title: How Easy Is It to Understand What Donald Trump Says?
text:
Linsear Write Formula
Like the previous metric, the Linsear Write Formula uses words with three or more syllables to compute text readability. It also relies on the sentence length to measure how difficult reading a text could be.


Code
create_plot(linsear_write_formula, subtitle = 'The Linsear Write Formula measures the complexity of a text document. Larger values indicate more difficult writings.')

title: How Easy Is It to Understand What Donald Trump Says?
text:
Dale-Chall Readability Score
This metric is different from the other metrics that we have talked about. It uses a dictionary of 3000 words that are easy to read and understand for a fourth-grade student. So, words that are not in this dictionary are considered to be complex. The higher the Dale-Chall Score is, the more difficult it is to read a text.


Code
create_plot(dale_chall_readability_score,subtitle = 'The Dale-Chall Readability Score measures the complexity of a text document. The higher the Dale-Chall Score is, the more difficult it is to read a text.')

title: How Easy Is It to Understand What Donald Trump Says?
text:
A Unified Readability Score
We introduced several readability metrics, but each one of them might give us a slightly different result. There is a way in textstat to combine all these metrics and have a single readability metric.


Code
us_election_speeches %>%
  filter(speaker %in% speakers) %>%
  mutate(text_standard = str_replace(text_standard,' and ','-'),
        text_standard = factor(
    text_standard,
    levels = c(
      '4th-5th grade',
      '5th-6th grade',
      '6th-7th grade',
      '7th-8th grade',
      '8th-9th grade',
      '9th-10th grade',
      '10th-11th grade',
      '11th-12th grade',
      '12th-13th grade',
      '14th-15th grade'
    )
  )) %>%
  count(speaker, text_standard) %>%
  mutate(n = n + 1) %>%
  ggplot()  +
  geom_col(aes(x = text_standard , y =  n, fill = speaker)) +
  labs(x = '', y = 'Number of Speeches', title = "How Easy Is It to Understand Trump's Speeches?",
       subtitle = 'Based on several readability tests, the education level that one needs to comprehend the 2020 Election speeches by different US politicians is illustrated in this plot.' ) +
  scale_fill_manual(values = custom_palette) +
  scale_y_log10() +
  facet_wrap(~ speaker, ncol = 1) +
  theme(axis.text  = element_text(size = 13),
        axis.title.y = element_text(size = 15,margin = margin(r = 10,l = 10)),
        plot.title = element_text(size = 20,margin = margin(b = 10,t = 10)),
        plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 14,margin = margin(b = 10)),
        strip.text = element_text(size = 15))


Interestingly, we can observe that Trump never gave a speech to an audience with difficulty more than the 7th or 8th grade. We can also convert this readability metric to numbers to visualize and compare it to other metrics.


Code
create_plot(text_standard_float,
            subtitle = 'The complexity of a text document was measured based on several readability metrics where larger values indicate more difficult writings.')

title: How Easy Is It to Understand What Donald Trump Says?
text:
Conclusion
We can consistently see that Trump’s speeches are less sophisticated and less complex than the speeches given by the rest of the politicians. We can attribute this to his lack of sophistication in terms of language, the fact that he knows how to speak to his audience, or both. Also, we can notice that Mike Pence and Barack Obama seem to use more advanced language in their speeches.

title: {delgosha}
text: {delgosha} is an R package that aims to provide a collection of ggplot2 themes specifically designed for Right-to-Left (RTL) languages, with a primary focus on Persian (Farsi). This package makes it easier for R users to create beautiful, publication-ready visualizations in Persian and other RTL languages.

title: {delgosha}
text: {delgosha} is an R package that aims to provide a collection of ggplot2 themes specifically designed for Right-to-Left (RTL) languages, with a primary focus on Persian (Farsi). This package makes it easier for R users to create beautiful, publication-ready visualizations in Persian and other RTL languages.

title: {delgosha}
text:
The Challenge
Creating data visualizations in RTL languages like Persian, Arabic, or Hebrew presents unique challenges:

Font support and rendering
Text alignment and direction
Label positioning
Theme compatibility with RTL text

title: {delgosha}
text:
Solution
{delgosha} provides:

RTL-Compatible Themes: Pre-configured ggplot2 themes optimized for RTL languages
Font Management: Easy integration with Persian fonts
Helper Functions: Utilities to simplify working with RTL text in ggplot2
Documentation: Comprehensive examples in both English and Persian

title: {delgosha}
text:
Key Features


For Users - Ready-to-use themes - Simple API - Persian font integration - Example gallery


For Developers - Clean, documented code - Extensible architecture - Unit tests - CI/CD pipeline

title: {delgosha}
text:
Technologies Used

R: Package development
ggplot2: Visualization framework
roxygen2: Documentation
testthat: Testing framework
GitHub Actions: Continuous integration

title: {delgosha}
text:
Package Philosophy
The name “delgosha” (دلگشا) means “heartwarming” or “delightful” in Persian, reflecting the package’s goal to make data visualization in Persian a delightful experience rather than a frustrating one.

title: {delgosha}
text:
Installation
# Install from GitHub
# install.packages("devtools")
devtools::install_github("mcnakhaee/delgosha")

title: {delgosha}
text:
Basic Usage
library(delgosha)
library(ggplot2)

# Create a plot with Persian theme
ggplot(iris, aes(x = Sepal.Length, y = Sepal.Width)) +
  geom_point() +
  theme_delgosha()

title: {delgosha}
text:
Project Links






TipAccess the Package




GitHub Repository: github.com/mcnakhaee/delgosha
Documentation: Full documentation and examples available in the repository

title: {delgosha}
text:
Impact
This package helps: - Persian-speaking R users create better visualizations - Researchers publish work in Persian journals - Students learn data visualization in their native language - The R community become more inclusive and multilingual

title: {delgosha}
text:
What I Learned
Building {delgosha} taught me: - R package development best practices - Working with fonts and text rendering in R - Internationalization and localization challenges - The importance of accessible tools for non-English speakers - How to build and maintain open-source software

Open source project available on GitHub

title: TidyTuesday
text: TidyTuesday is a weekly data project aimed at the R ecosystem. Every week, a new dataset is posted, and participants create visualizations and share their work on social media. This repository contains my submissions for the weekly TidyTuesday Project, created using R and ggplot2.

title: TidyTuesday
text: TidyTuesday is a weekly data project aimed at the R ecosystem. Every week, a new dataset is posted, and participants create visualizations and share their work on social media. This repository contains my submissions for the weekly TidyTuesday Project, created using R and ggplot2.

title: TidyTuesday
text:
About TidyTuesday
The TidyTuesday project is:

A safe and supportive forum for individuals to practice their data wrangling and visualization skills
A weekly social data project that focuses on understanding data
An opportunity to work with real-world datasets and create compelling visualizations

title: TidyTuesday
text:
Key Features

Weekly Visualizations: Regular contributions exploring diverse datasets
R & ggplot2: All visualizations created using R’s powerful ggplot2 package
Data Storytelling: Each visualization tells a unique story about the data
Reproducible Code: All code is available for learning and reproduction

title: TidyTuesday
text:
Technologies Used


Languages & Tools - R - ggplot2 - tidyverse - RStudio


Skills Demonstrated - Data wrangling - Statistical visualization - Design principles - Data storytelling

title: TidyTuesday
text:
Sample Visualizations
My TidyTuesday submissions cover a wide range of topics and datasets, including:

Economic trends and indicators
Social and demographic data
Sports statistics
Environmental data
Cultural and entertainment data

Each visualization is crafted to: - Clearly communicate insights from the data - Follow best practices in data visualization - Use effective color schemes and typography - Be accessible and easy to understand

title: TidyTuesday
text:
Project Links






TipView My Work




GitHub Repository: github.com/mcnakhaee/Tidy-Tuesday
Explore my weekly submissions and see how different datasets can be visualized

title: TidyTuesday
text:
What I Learned
Participating in TidyTuesday has helped me: - Develop stronger data visualization skills - Learn to work with diverse datasets quickly - Understand design principles for effective communication - Build a portfolio of data visualization work - Engage with the R community

Ongoing project with weekly contributions

title: Project Images
text:
This directory should contain the following images for the project cards:



tidytuesday.png - TidyTuesday project thumbnail

Recommended size: 400x300px or similar aspect ratio
Should show a sample TidyTuesday visualization

delgosha.png - Delgosha R package thumbnail

Recommended size: 400x300px or similar aspect ratio
Could show Persian text visualization or package logo

palmer.png - Palmer Penguins package thumbnail

Recommended size: 400x300px or similar aspect ratio
Could show penguin illustrations or sample visualization






Images are referenced in the respective project index.qmd files
If images are missing, Quarto will still render but show placeholder or no image
You can copy these images from your old Distill blog’s imgs/ directory
Supported formats: PNG, JPG, SVG





TidyTuesday: projects/projects/tidytuesday/tidytuesday.png
Delgosha: projects/projects/delgosha/delgosha.png
Palmer Penguins: projects/projects/palmerpenguins/palmer.png

title: Projects
text:
A collection of my open-source projects, packages, and data visualization work. Each project represents a commitment to making data science more accessible and creating tools that serve the community.


From R and Python packages to weekly data visualizations, explore the projects below to see how I combine technical skills with a passion for open-source software and data storytelling.

title: Projects
text: From R and Python packages to weekly data visualizations, explore the projects below to see how I combine technical skills with a passion for open-source software and data storytelling.

title: About Muhammad Chenariyan Nakhaee
text:
I’m a data analyst/scientist currently working at Exact in the Netherlands. Before that, I worked as a researcher at the University of Twente. Welcome to my personal website!
Also known as: Muhammad Nakhaee, Muhammad C. Nakhaee




I specialize in full-stack development and data science, with a particular interest in creating intuitive user experiences and deriving insights from data.



Building modern web applications with cutting-edge technologies. I focus on clean code, scalability, and user experience.
Technologies: - JavaScript/TypeScript - React, Node.js - Python - Databases & APIs



Transforming data into actionable insights through analysis and visualization. I love finding patterns and telling stories with data.
Skills: - Data analysis - Machine learning - Visualization - Statistical modeling



Sharing knowledge through talks, workshops, and writing. I believe in giving back to the community and helping others grow.
Topics: - Web development - Data visualization - Best practices - Career development






Education: - University of Twente - Researcher
Experience: - Data Analyst/Scientist at Exact (Present) - Researcher at University of Twente (Previously)




When I’m not coding or analyzing data, you can find me:

 Reading about technology and science
 Hiking and exploring nature
 Photography
 Listening to music and podcasts
 Trying new coffee shops






[Award Name] - [Organization], 2024
Published Article - “[Article Title]” in [Publication]
Open Source Contributor - [Project Names]
Community Leader - Organized [Event/Meetup]





I’m always interested in connecting with fellow developers, data enthusiasts, and interesting people. Feel free to reach out!






NoteContact Information




 GitHub: github.com/mcnakhaee
 Twitter: @m_cnakhaee
 LinkedIn: linkedin.com/in/muhammadcnakhaee
 Instagram: @mcnakhaee








This website is built using Quarto, a modern scientific and technical publishing system. Previously, I used the {distill} package and Hugo with the blogdown package.






TipLet’s Connect!



I’m always interested in connecting with fellow data scientists, developers, and researchers. Feel free to reach out through any of my social channels!

title: Deployment Workflow - Pre-Rendered Site
text:
Your Quarto website is now configured to be rendered locally and then deployed to Netlify as a static site. This approach is simpler and avoids the need to install R on Netlify’s build servers.




Local Rendering: You render the site on your local machine (where R is installed)
Git Tracking: The _site folder is tracked in Git (not ignored)
Netlify Deployment: Netlify simply serves the pre-built files from the _site folder







Make changes to your .qmd files, projects, or blog posts
Render locally:
quarto render
Commit and push:
git add -A
git commit -m "Update site content"
git push origin quarto
Netlify automatically deploys the updated _site folder







[build]
  command = ""  # No build command - site is pre-rendered
  publish = "_site"



# _site/ is commented out so it's tracked in Git
/.quarto/
**/*.quarto_ipynb




✅ Simple: No complex build setup on Netlify
✅ Fast: Netlify just serves files, no rendering needed
✅ Reliable: Builds happen locally where you control the environment
✅ R Support: Full R support since you render where R is installed
✅ Preview: You can test the site locally before deploying




Always run quarto render before committing
The _site folder will be large (contains all HTML, CSS, JS, images)
Make sure to push the _site folder to Git
Netlify will deploy automatically when you push to the quarto branch




If Netlify deployment fails: 1. Check that _site folder exists and is pushed to Git 2. Verify netlify.toml has publish = "_site" 3. Check Netlify build logs for any errors

Your site should now deploy successfully on Netlify! 🎉
